documents.title: Eye Gaze in Autism Spectrum Disorder
keyFindings: Reduced eye contact is an early indicator of developmental concerns
Fixation duration of 200-300ms is typical for ages 6-10
Atypical gaze patterns can be measured quantitatively
Social attention differs in ASD vs typical development
Eye-tracking provides objective assessment of attention

documents.title: Eye-Tracking Technology in Healthcare
keyFindings: Eye-tracking provides objective, quantifiable attention data
Saccade velocity of 250-350Â°/s indicates normal oculomotor function
Cognitive load can be measured through pupil dilation
Visual search efficiency correlates with attention capacity
Eye-tracking useful for diagnosis and monitoring

documents.title: Eye Gazing Benefits
keyFindings: Sustained eye contact builds social connection
Focus training through gaze exercises enhances attention span
Eye gazing reduces anxiety through controlled practice
